fr:title.text: A more abstract formulation of locally small family fibrations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A more abstract formulation of locally small family fibrations

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We will reformulate the local smallness property of the family fibration in a way that uses only the language that makes sense for an arbitrary cartesian fibration, though for now we stick with \boldsymbol {\mathcal {F}}_{C}. Given u,v\in \boldsymbol {\mathcal {F}}_{C}[I], we have a “relative hom family” {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}\in {\mathbf {Set}}_{/I}. The fact that each {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}_{i} is the set of all morphisms u_{i}\to v_{i} can be rephrased more abstractly.
First we consider the restriction of u\in \boldsymbol {\mathcal {F}}_{C}[I] to \boldsymbol {\mathcal {F}}_{C}[{\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}] as follows:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { nw/style = pullback, west/style = lies over, east/style = lies over, north/style = {->,exists}, height = 1.5cm, nw = {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}^{*}u, ne = u, sw = {{\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}}, se = I, south = p_{{\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}}, north = \bar {p}_{{\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}} }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Explicitly the family {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}^{*}u is indexed in a pair of an element i\in I and a morphism u_{i}\to v_{i}. We can think of {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}^{*}u as the object of elements of u_{i} indexed in pairs (i,u_{i}\to v_{i}).

There is a canonical map \epsilon _{{\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}}:{\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}^{*}u\xrightarrow [p_{{\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}}]{} v that “evaluates” each indexing morphism u_{i}\to v_{i}.

That each {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}_{i} is the set of all morphisms u_{i}\to v_{i} can be rephrased as a universal property: for any family h\in {\mathbf {Set}}_{/I} and morphism \epsilon _{h} : h^{*}u\xrightarrow [h]{} v in \boldsymbol {\mathcal {F}}_{C}, there is a unique cartesian map h^{*}u\to {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}^{*}u factoring \epsilon _{h} through \epsilon _{{\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}} in the sense depicted below:

To convince ourselves of this, we note that the family H \coloneqq {\mathopen {}\left \{u_{i}\to v_{i}\right \}\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} itself satisfies the universal property above. Indeed, fix a candidate h \in {\mathbf {Set}}_{/I} equipped with a map \epsilon _{h} : h^{*}u \xrightarrow [h]{} v. Unfolding the meaning of this map in set theoretical notation, we see that it amounts to a family of maps \epsilon _{h}[i] : \prod _{x\in h_i} {\mathopen {}\left \{u_i\to v_i\right \}\mathclose {}} for each i\in I; such a family immediately induces the desired map h\to H.
There are a number of (equivalent) variations on the definition of a locally small fibration. We attempt to provide some intuition for these definitions.

An ordinary category E is called locally small when for any x,y\in E the collection of morphisms x\to y is a set. This property of E can be rephrased in terms of its family fibration \boldsymbol {\mathcal {F}}_{E} over \mathbf {Set} as follows.

Consider an index set I\in \mathbf {Set} and two families u,v\in C^I. We may define an I-indexed collection {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} consisting (pointwise) of all the morphisms u_{i}\to v_{i} in C:

If C is locally small, {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} is in fact a family of sets for any I\in \mathbf {Set} as each {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}_{i} is a set. Conversely, if {\mathopen {}\left [u,v\right ]\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} is a family of sets for any I\in \mathbf {Set}, then C is locally small as we may consider in particular the case that I=\mathbf {1}.

Based on our explorations above, we are now prepared to write down (and understand) the proper definition of local smallness for an arbitrary cartesian fibration E over B, which should be thought of as a (potentially large) category relative to B.
For any x\in B and displayed objects u,v\in E_{x}, we define a hom candidate for u,v to be a span u\leftarrow \bar {h} \rightarrow v in E in which the left-hand leg is cartesian:

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In the above, h should be thought of as a candidate for the “hom object” of u,v, and \epsilon _{h} should be viewed as the structure of an “evaluation map” for h. This structure can be rephrased in terms of a displayed category \mathbf {H}_{E_{x}}(u,v) over {B}_{/x}:

html:ol.html:li: Given h\in {B}_{/x}, an object of \mathbf {H}_{E_{x}}(u,v)_{h} is given by a hom candidate whose apex in the base is h itself. We will write \bar {h} metonymically for the entire hom candidate over h.

html:li.html:p: Given \alpha :l\to h\in {B}_{/x} and hom candidates \bar {l}\in \mathbf {H}_{E_{x}}(u,v)_{l} and \bar {h}\in \mathbf {H}_{E_{x}}(u,v)_{h}, a morphism \bar {h}\xrightarrow [\alpha ]{} \bar {l} is given by a cartesian morphism \bar \alpha :\bar {l}\xrightarrow [\alpha ]{}\bar {h} in E such that the following diagram commutes:

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A cartesian fibration E over B is locally small if and only if for each x\in B and u,v\in E_{x}, the total category \widetilde {\mathbf {H}_{E_{x}}(u,v)} of hom candidates has a terminal object. Viewed as a displayed object in E, we shall write \overline {\mathbf {hom}}_{E_{x}}(u,v) lying over \mathbf {hom}_{E_{x}}{\mathopen {}\left (u,v\right )\mathclose {}} for the terminal hom candidate.
